titleStmt.title: An Encoded Transcription of Material from the Sylvia Beach Papers

msIdentifier.repository: Princeton University. Library. Dept. of Rare Books and Special Collections

change.ab: Transcribed cards. s1: <*> = "Segur"? related to tel. number arrow drawn from "30" to "given to daughter" <*> = "centra"? "Morte d'Arthur ..." <*> = note next to "Lady Chatterley" very unclear PD written over all of it s2: "Budenbrooks" = "Buddenbrooks"? (Mann) <*> = no idea "Rutibaga stories" = "Rootabaga Stories"? (Sandburg) <*> = empty box with arrow from "March 15" Attached to bottom of s2 is a newspaper obit of Bertha C. Child

Mrs. Bertha C. Child N.Y. Herald Dies in Hospital Here Feb 10 Mrs. Bertha Cushing Child, 61-year- old American musician who has re- sided in Paris for the past seven years, died suddenly at the American Hos- pital at 10.40 a.m. yesterday as the result of meningitis. The body will be cremated tomorrow. Funeral services, to be held today, are strictly private. Until her retirement several years ago Mrs. Child was well known in musical circles in America as a con- tralto. She sang with the Boston Symphony Orchestra and other out- standing organizations. Since coming to France she had been living at 7 rue Servandoni. She is survived by two sons and one daughter. The latter, Meeda Munro, is Paris corres- pondent for "Town and Country." One son, Charles Child, is en route to France on the Leviathan, following a cable from his sister yesterday. An- other son, Paul, is in America.
